documentType: Bureau of Prisons incident report and memoranda
summary: This document is a collection of Bureau of Prisons forms and memoranda detailing the discovery, medical response, and aftermath of Jeffrey Epstein's death by suicide in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York, on August 10, 2019. It includes the initial incident report, staff accounts of the response, and medical records.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The inmate found unresponsive in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York, on August 10, 2019. He was pronounced dead at the hospital.

persons.name: N' Diaye, L
persons.context: Submitted the initial Form 583 Report of Incident (NYM-19-0082) regarding Epstein's death.

persons.name: Noel, Tova
persons.context: Listed in the incident report as 'Others Involved'. No injury reported.

persons.name: Thomas, Michael
persons.context: Listed in the incident report as 'Others Involved'. No injury reported.

persons.name: Adams, G
persons.context: Responded to the hospital to watch Epstein's remains and provided a timeline of the morgue transfer.

persons.name: Wiggins
persons.role: Director of Office of City Medical Examiner (OCME)
persons.context: Communicated with the Institution Duty Officer regarding the transportation of Epstein's remains to the city morgue.

persons.name: Darden, J
persons.context: Recipient of a memorandum from a Clinical Nurse regarding the medical emergency.

persons.name: Ono, J
persons.context: Provided a detailed clinical account of the medical response to Epstein's unresponsive state, noting circumferential bruising.

persons.name: Dupree
persons.context: Assisted in retrieving medical equipment (stretcher, AED) during the response to the body alarm.

connections.description: N' Diaye was the staff member who formally reported the incident of Epstein's death.
Clinical Nurse Ono provided direct medical assessment and care during the resuscitation attempt.
Officer Adams was part of the detail that coordinated with Director Wiggins of OCME for the transfer of Epstein's remains.

events.title: Discovery of Epstein Unresponsive
events.description: At approximately 6:33 a.m., Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell (9 South SHU, cell #220) at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York.

events.title: Medical Response and Transport
events.description: Staff initiated CPR, called EMS, and transported Epstein to the Health Services unit. EMS arrived at 6:43 a.m. and transported him to New York Presbyterian – Lower Manhattan Hospital at approximately 7:10 a.m.

events.title: Pronouncement of Death
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was pronounced deceased at the hospital at 7:36 a.m. due to cardiac arrest.

events.title: Remains Transferred to OCME
events.description: Epstein's remains were prepared at the hospital morgue and transferred to the Office of the City Medical Examiner (OCME) city morgue, with staff from OCME departing the hospital at 12:57 p.m.

events.title: Staff Instructed Not to Speak to Media
events.description: A lieutenant instructed escorting staff not to speak to anyone or the media regarding the situation and to direct inquiries to the MCC NY Public Relations Officer.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York (150 Park Row, New York, NY 10007)
New York Presbyterian – Lower Manhattan Hospital (170 William Street, New York, NY 10038)
Office of the City Medical Examiner (OCME) city morgue
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York, on August 10, 2019, at approximately 6:33 a.m.
Medical staff noted 'circumferential bruising around the neck' upon initial assessment.
Epstein was pronounced dead at a local hospital at 7:36 a.m. The incident was classified as a suicide by hanging/asphyxiation in the initial report.
BOP staff were instructed not to speak to the media or anyone about the incident and to direct all inquiries to the Public Relations Officer.
Epstein's remains were transferred from the hospital to the New York City Office of the Chief Medical Examiner's morgue on the same day.
